2. They could be aiming for a higher total payoff (>45$) by always choosing R and hoping I choose B, or vice versa.
3. They could try to maximize their average payoff per round (closer to 40$) by picking the strategy that gives them the most advantage in each round, regardless of what I pick.
4. They could employ a mix of these strategies, or even adapt their approach as the game progresses based on my responses.

Since we don't know our opponent's strategy, I would choose a mixed strategy myself to increase my chances of achieving a better outcome overall. One such strategy could involve picking R in roughly 50% of the rounds and B in the other half. This way, if our opponents are playing randomly, we have a good chance of getting an average payoff close to 43.75$ (which is the arithmetic mean of 35$, 40$, and 45$).

If our opponent always chooses R or B, then this strategy would allow us to capitalize on their mistakes by earning 45$ whenever they make a mistake against us. And if our opponent is adaptive, switching between strategies based on our choices, we might still achieve an average payoff close to 43.75$.

Overall, I believe the optimal choice for me would be to pick R about half the time and B the other half. Therefore, my choice would be {R} (with R denoting 'rock' or 'right', depending on how you interpret the game).
